text.text_translated:
Technology and health care got better in the last two hundred years.  
Fewer children died young.  
Population got bigger.  
Large families had more children.  
The children lived and got big.  
They had their own children.  
In the 1960s, contraception (a way to stop having babies) got easier.  
The average number of babies per woman in the world went down.  
It went down from six babies per woman to two.

best_attempt.text_translated:
In the last 200 years, technology got better.  
People got better health care.  
Fewer children died young.  
These changes are fuelling rapid population growth.  
Families had many children.  
Many children grew up and had children too.  
Contraception is how people stop a woman having a baby.  
In the 1960s, people could use contraception.  
The global average number of babies per woman was six.  
Then it fell to two.
